utterances: Now, did you talk to the producers at all about any of these?
And if so, what did you say and what did they say?
I talked to the producers and I told them that I wanted to leave.
And the producers told me that that was my choice.

And then there were people - and I don't know how much of this I can say - but there were people in the house that - you'll see the last scene where there's several of us in a room and those people came to me and said, Shalonda, don't leave.

Give us a chance, trust us that we have your best interests in heart and that we care about you and we don't want you to be unhappy and uncomfortable, and just give us tonight to figure out what we're going to do and how we're going to handle it.
And you were not the only person, we should point out to the audience, who was victimized by this Dennis person.
There was some homophobia involved there and there was some misogyny going on.
There were all sorts of bad things happening that make unfortunately for good reality TV.
Yes.
I think it made for great reality TV.
And the hard part was being there and seeing those things happen.
And I don't if you actually see me get up and walk away because I said, this is too much for me and I know that I know that this guy is drunk.
And he didn't graduate with you, he graduated a year later, the show said.
So was he - he just was a plant then, I surmise.
I did see Dennis at the premier.
We went to a premier in Arizona where all of the cast went - well, the majority of the castâ€¦
Now, how did that go?
He had - he was drinking and having a good time.
He wasn't offensive, but he definitely had some things that would require more attention than we could've given him in the two-week Hawaii retreat.
All right, final thing is this, this was your 20-year reunion, right?
So you're going to go to the 25?
Absolutely, absolutely.
That one person does not make or break me, and the relationships that I developed with my other - with the other people on the show was just incredible.
OK.
Well, I appreciate your coming on.
It was interesting, a little painful but interesting to watch.
(Laughing) And the pain continues.
I do believe the saga will continue next week as well.
Shalonda, thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Tony.
That was Shalonda Warren-Clark, she was one of the participants in ""High School Reunion, the Class of '88,"" now showing on TV Land.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan, in Washington.
Sixty-six years after the Wright Brothers made history at Kitty Hawk, Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin stepped onto the surface of the moon.

From that pivotal moment on, Aldrin has advocated for continued and expanded space exploration, and now he argues that 66 years after the Eagle landed at Tranquility Base, Americans should establish a presence on Mars.
Not just a single trip or a moment in history, he calls for systematic investment to establish a cycle of transportation and sustained, permanent settlements on the Red Planet.
He's got a plan on how to develop the political will to commit to that ambitious goal and ideas about how to pay for it, too.
If you have questions for Buzz Aldrin about Mars and the feasibility of human exploration of space, give us a call: 800-989-8255.
Email: talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our website.
That's at npr.org.
Click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Later in the program, the technology that gives women the choice to freeze their eggs and reschedule motherhood.
But first, Buzz Aldrin joins us here in Studio 42 to talk about his new book, ""Mission to Mars."" Nice to have you on TALK OF THE NATION today.
Well thank you.
It's a pleasure to be here with you, and reaching a lot of people out there.
Well, as you describe it in the book, the technology to do all this is within reach, or close enough.
At a time, though, of budget cuts and arguments that government is too small, how do you excite the American people enough to generate the political will for such a program?
I think we're talking ourselves into this gloomsday period.
What we need is leadership willing to look out into the future, and not what's in it for me right now.
There's just too much of this graveling - groveling around, trying to get political favors for a particular district and not looking 20, 30 years into the middle of the 21st century.
We have great opportunities in front of us, and I think we haven't done all that well in the past.
And because of that, not only am I putting forth my own plan for the future, but I'm forming a foundation that should look at the evolution of space policy.

Since the very beginnings of rocket travel, we've had a policy of some sort coming out of the executive branch, and then the legislative branch decides maybe how to oversee that, diddle around with it a little here or there.
And in the process, they bring home the bacon to whatever constituency they represent - not that that isn't a good idea.
You certainly elect someone, and you expect them to do good things for the people who elected them.
Yeah.
But you're...

But if it's carried to an extreme, we are sacrificing the long-range objectives of a nation just so that somebody can keep jobs going and working on the same thing instead of new, innovative ideas that help to make us true leaders in space in the 21st century.
There's no doubt who was a leader in space after the Apollo Program.
Nobody came close to us.
And our education system, in science, technology, engineering and math, was at the top of the world.
It's no longer there.
We're descending rather rapidly.
You talk about leadership, though.
The past two presidents have both outlined ambitious programs and don't seem to be coming anywhere near to finding the funding to pay for it.
Well, who's at fault there?
We need a budget, and we need a budget that is accepted by the people.
We need policies that are put forth.

I can show a way to get there through the judicious use of foreign policy and the choices, the things that we've done in the past, and how we can make use of bringing people together in a cooperative way at the moon, so that each one can achieve what they would like to do.
For the most part, it's prestige for their individual country, just like it was for Russia, and just like it was for the United States.
It was more than prestige that was behind the space race.
That was not just to show off we've got the best and the brightest.
You control the moon, you control the Earth.
There was an existential threat there.
Well, wait a minute?
What do you mean, you control the moon, you control the Earth?
I don't understand what you mean.
There was great fear.
There was a military aspect to this.
There was.
Yeah.
OK.
Well, I'm a military guy.
You are.
You were a jet fighter pilot.
So you ought to know better than I do.
And our bullets don't quite go that far.
No, but there was an aspect of that competition that fueled - it was more than just...
There was the technology that was developed by utilizing computers to solve difficult problems, utilizing medical developments that enabled us to take better care of our troops.
Certainly, the miniaturization that went into nuclear weapons was used in the space program, not the other way around.
Ten thousand, six hundred and twenty-eight fewer victims of crimes in the city of Memphis.

You really felt for this little boy growing up in the Tennessee mountains.
It made my heart sing, and I thought it was actually the truth.
